===Social and environmental policy=== ===="Look Behind the Label"==== In 2006, the ''Look Behind the Label'' marketing campaign was introduced."[http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/timeforpaddington/ti_news_detail.asp?newsID=63 M&S launches new ‘Look behind the label' campaign] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928024224/http://www.paddingtonwaterside.co.uk/timeforpaddington/ti_news_detail.asp?newsID=63 |date=28 September 2007 }}". Paddington Waterside Partnership – 21 February 2006 The aim of this campaign was to highlight to customers the various ethical and environmentally friendly aspects of the production and sourcing methods engaged in by M&S including: [[Fairtrade]] products, [[sustainable fishing]] and environmentally friendly textile dyes. All coffee and tea sold in M&S stores is now Fairtrade."[http://www.foodnavigator.com/news/ng.asp?id=66333-marks-spencer-fairtrade-coffee Marks & Spencer dives into ethical consumer market]" Fletcher, Anthony – 10 March 2006 – Food Navigator.com (Europe) In addition, the company offers clothing lines made from Fairtrade cotton in selected departments."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4660410.stm M&S set to launch Fairtrade range]". BBC News Online – 30 January 2006 At Christmas, the company introduces a range of food products to support the housing charity [[Shelter (charity)|Shelter]]."[http://england.shelter.org.uk/howtohelp/howtohelp-682.cfm Marks & Spencer raises money for Shelter this Christmas]" (dead link) [[File:MarksAndSpencerBirmingham.jpg|thumb|M&S store on [[Birmingham]] High Street]] On 15 January 2007, M&S launched an initiative, known as "Plan A",{{cite web|url=http://plana.marksandspencer.com/ |title=Plan A |publisher=Plana.marksandspencer.com |accessdate=18 April 2011}} to dramatically increase the environmental [[sustainability]] of the business within 5 years and expected to cost £200 million.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6261939.stm |title=Business | M&S unveils carbon-neutral target |publisher=BBC News |date=15 January 2007 |accessdate=7 November 2009}} The plan covers "100 commitments over 5 years to address the key social and environmental challenges facing M&S today and in the future" with the tag-line "Because there is no Plan B". The commitments span five themes: [[climate change]], [[waste]], sustainable raw materials, 'fair partnership' and health, with the aim that, by 2012, it will:[http://plana.marksandspencer.com/index.php?action=PublicPillarDisplay Marks & Spencer: Plan A – The Five Pillars], Marks & Spencer * Become carbon neutral * Send no waste to landfill * Extend sustainable sourcing * Help improve the lives of people in their supply chain * Help customers and employees live a healthier life-style Despite an 18% fall in the share price in January 2008, following publication of their latest [[trading statement]], the company confirmed that they would be continuing with the plan, saying that there were 'compelling commercial — as well as moral — reasons to do so'.[https://web.archive.org/web/20081206094008/http://www.hbrgreen.org/2008/03/the_hard_economics_of_green.html?cm_mmc=npv-_-listserv-_-MAR_2008-_-HBRGreen0305 The hard economics of green], [[Harvard Business Review]], [[Stuart Rose|Sir Stuart Rose]], published 4 March 2008 M&S introduced a reusable [[Hessian (cloth)|hessian]] bag in 2007 as part of the plan, aiming to reduce the number of plastic bags used within five years. This was followed in May 2008 by the introduction of a 5p charge for standard sized carrier bags used for food purchases (before this charge became compulsory).{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7268283.stm |title=M&S to charge 5p for plastic bags |publisher=BBC News |date=28 February 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} All profits from the sale of food bags originally went to the charity [[Groundwork UK]];[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jhtml?xml=/earth/2008/02/28/eaplastic128.xml "Marks and Spencer to charge for plastic bags"], By Bonnie Malkin and agencies, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (online), 28 February 2008 M&S launched the "Forever Fish" campaign in June 2011 and switched funding to that campaign to promote protection of marine wildlife in the UK.[http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/page.aspx?pointerid=7337418c9e6a4eb2a97b7016192e0ee4 "Marks & Spencer launches Forever Fish"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322220938/http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/page.aspx?pointerid=7337418c9e6a4eb2a97b7016192e0ee4 |date=22 March 2012 }}, Marks and Spencer Press Release, 7 June 2011 In becoming carbon neutral the company has committed to only use [[carbon offset]]ting as a last resort,[http://plana.marksandspencer.com/index.php?action=PublicAboutPlanDetailDisplay&pillar_id=1&cur_page=2 Marks & Spencer: Plan A – The Plan – Climate change], Marks & Spencer restricted to cases "where it is required by government or where the technology for green air or road transport will not be available for the foreseeable future".[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6262453.stm Rose goes green in pursuit of profit], [[BBC]], published 15 January 2007 As of August 2008, M&S had three [[wind turbines]] in operation, one at [[Methlick]] and two near [[Strichen]], generating enough power to supply three stores via the [[National Grid (UK)|National Grid]].[http://www.banffshire-journal.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/3048/Turbines_add_to_M_S_green_energy_plan.html Turbines add to M&S green energy plan] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090214121851/http://www.banffshire-journal.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/3048/Turbines_add_to_M_S_green_energy_plan.html |date=14 February 2009 }}, Bannfshire Journal, published 5 August 2008 In April 2009 the company began purchasing 2.6 [[TWh]] of renewable energy (wind and hydroelectric) from [[Npower (UK)|Npower]], enough to power all Marks & Spencer stores and offices in England and Wales.{{cite web|url=http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/media/press_releases/company/pressrelease_16.09.09 |title=M&S & Npower Sign UK Retail's Biggest Renewable Energy Contract |date=February 2009 |publisher=Marks and Spencer |accessdate=17 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429090438/http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/media/press_releases/company/pressrelease_16.09.09 |archivedate=29 April 2009 }} In 2012 the company was awarded [[European Business Awards for the Environment|European Business Award for the Environment]] (Management category) by the [[European Union]] for Plan A.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/awards/winners_2012.html#management_award|title=Winners 2012 |publisher= European Commission|accessdate= 22 November 2015}} ====Charity work==== M&S has sold a wide range of charitable women's clothes for [[Breakthrough Breast Cancer]]{{cite journal|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/favourites-of-vogue/2010/09/marks-and-spencer-breakthrough-breast-cancer|journal=Vogue| title=M and S For Breakthrough| date=3 September 2010| first=Jessica| last=Bumpus| accessdate=5 August 2015}} for many years and the [[Ashbourne, Derbyshire|Ashbourne]] store collected a total of £2,000 for a local [[Derbyshire]] hospital's new ECG machine in 2010.{{Cite news| url=http://www.ashbournenewstelegraph.co.uk/News/Not-just-any-ECG-machine.htm |title=Not just any ECG machine|publisher=Ashbourne News & Telegraph|date=20 October 2010|accessdate=25 March 2012}} In 2011 M&S launch [[Oxfam]]'s clothes recycling initiative.{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfam.org.uk/fashion-blog/2013/01/marks-and-spencer-shwop-shop-with-oxfam| title=Marks & Spencer and Oxfam Shwop Shop |publisher=Oxfam.org |date=5 January 2013| first=Helen| last=Archard |accessdate=5 August 2015}} ===Senior management=== The following have served as the Chairman of the company since it was founded: * 1884–1907: [[Michael Marks]] (set up first stall in Leeds in 1884) * 1907–1916: William Chapman.{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/marks-and-spencer-p-l-c |title=Marks and Spencer plc |publisher=answers.com |accessdate=18 April 2011}} * 1916–1964: [[Simon Marks]] (Lord Marks) * 1964–1967: [[Israel Sieff]] (Lord Sieff) * 1967–1972: [[Edward Sieff]] * 1972–1984: [[Marcus Sieff]] (Lord Sieff) * 1984–1991: [[Derek Rayner, Baron Rayner|Derek Rayner]] (Lord Rayner) * 1991–1999: [[Richard Greenbury|Sir Richard Greenbury]] * 2000–2004: Luc Vandevelde * 2004–2006: [[Paul Myners]] * 2006–2009: [[Terence Burns, Baron Burns|Lord Burns]] * 2009–2010: [[Sir Stuart Rose]] * 2011–2017: [[Robert Swannell]] * 2017-present: [[Archie Norman]] ==Stores== ===UK and Ireland=== [[File:A picture of M&S White City branch in Westfield London 2014-01-17 17-26.jpg|thumb|M&S White City in [[Westfield London]] is one of the company's largest stores.]] The largest shop is at [[Marble Arch]], on [[Oxford Street]] in London, which has around {{convert|16000|m2}} of [[shop floor]]. The second largest is in Cheshire Oaks, [[Ellesmere Port]], which is the largest outside London.{{cite web|url=http://www.propertyweek.com/story.asp?sectioncode=36&storycode=3103910&c=1 |title=M&S megastore for Leeds — Property Week |publisher=Property Week|accessdate=7 November 2009}} The third largest shop is at the Gemini Retail Park in [[Warrington]]. In 1999 M&S opened its shop in [[Manchester]]'s [[Exchange Square (Manchester)|Exchange Square]], which was destroyed in the [[1996 Manchester bombing]] and rebuilt. At re-opening, it was the largest M&S shop with {{convert|250000|sqft|m2|abbr=on|order=flip}} of retail space, but half was subsequently sold to [[Selfridges]], the company's second site in Manchester. The smallest branch is an outlet located in the [[Grainger Market]] in Newcastle upon Tyne.{{cite web|url=http://www.newcastlegateshead.com/things-to-do/grainger-market-p433811|title=Grainger Market|publisher=Newcastle Gateshead|accessdate=20 March 2015}} M&S has opened a number of stores at out of town locations since the trend to build shopping centres away from town centres became popular in the 1980s. The first was at the [[MetroCentre (shopping centre)|MetroCentre]], [[Gateshead]], [[Tyne and Wear]], which opened in 1986. Another notable example is the store at the [[Merry Hill Shopping Centre]] at [[Brierley Hill]], West Midlands. This store opened on 23 October 1990 shortly after the closure of stores in the nearby town centres of [[Dudley]] and [[West Bromwich]]; the Merry Hill store was not originally intended to replace these two town centre stores, but both the Dudley and West Bromwich stores had experienced a downturn in trade as the opening of the Merry Hill store loomed, and both stores were closed on 25 August 1990.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120106032922/http://www.sthelens.oxon.sch.uk/Geography/Downloads/Geopress%20Factsheets/Geo%20factsheets/11%20out%20of%20town%20shopping%20centres.pdf Out Of Town Shopping Centres] Geofactsheet No. 11 Before Christmas 2006, twenty-two M&S shops were open for 24-hour trading including the recently opened new retail park stores at [[Bolton]] Middlebrook and at the Abbey Centre, [[Newtownabbey]], Northern Ireland."[http://www.marksandspencer.com/gp/browse.html/ref=sc_fe_c_1/026-7667460-4435653?ie=UTF8&node=51065031&no=51237031&mnSBrand=core&me=A2BO0OYVBKIQJM Marks & Spencer announces pre Christmas opening hours]" Press Release – 8 December 2006"[https://archive.is/20120710184134/http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/0750expats/expats/tm_headline=-m-s--opens-for-24hrs-and-other-department-stores-extend-hours-to-boost-slow-trading-&method=full&objectid=18289095&siteid=50082-name_page.html M&S opens for 24hrs and other department stores extend hours to boost slow trading]". Watson, Molly — icWales.co.uk – 20 December 2006 The company's website has received criticism for having its prices in [[Pound sterling]] and not in euro, and for providing a search for its Irish stores through a "UK Store Finder".{{cite web |url=http://www.sbpost.ie/post/pages/p/story.aspx-qqqt=COMPUTERS+IN+BUSINESS-qqqs=computersinbusiness-qqqid=37099-qqqx=1.asp |title=Sunday Business Post | Irish Business News |publisher=Sbpost.ie |date=2 November 2008 |accessdate=7 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625190709/http://www.sbpost.ie/post/pages/p/story.aspx-qqqt=COMPUTERS+IN+BUSINESS-qqqs=computersinbusiness-qqqid=37099-qqqx=1.asp |archivedate=25 June 2009 }} ''[[The Irish Times]]'' pointed out that M&S failed to explain why the company is in a position to deliver goods ordered from its website to Brazil, Argentina, Iraq and Afghanistan but not to Ireland. M&S did not comment.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/pricewatch/2010/0111/1224262050906.html |title=M&S Vouchers |work=The Irish TImes |date=1 January 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} ===International=== [[File:Marks & Spencer, The Mall Athens.JPG|thumb|A Marks & Spencer branch in [[Athens]]]] The company reopened its store in Paris on 24 November 2011, following the launch of a new French website on 11 October 2011.Rigby, Chloe [http://www.internetretailing.net/2011/10/ms-launches-new-french-website/ ''M&S launches new French website''] 11 October 2011, internetretailing.net In the Philippines there are 18 M&S shops, the largest of which is located in [[Greenbelt (Ayala Center)|Greenbelt Mall]]. A new store opened on 17 April 2013 in [[Kalverstraat]] in [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]], more than 10 years after closure of the previous store. On 17 September 2013 the British ambassador to the Netherlands, Sir Geoffrey Adams, opened the first Dutch Marks & Spencer Food pilot store at a BP petrol station in Bijleveld beside the A12 motorway.BP press release [http://www.bp.com/genericarticle.do?categoryId=16002516&contentId=7086707 ''BP opent vandaag eerste Marks & Spencer Food pilot in Nederland''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927092216/http://www.bp.com/genericarticle.do?categoryId=16002516&contentId=7086707 |date=27 September 2013 }} 10 September 2013, BPHorecatrends website [http://www.horecatrends.com/en/retail/marks-and-spencer-food-pilot-bij-bp-tankstation "Marks and Spencer Food pilot at BP gas station"] 12 September 2013, Horeca Trends There are over 300 stores in some 40 overseas locations.{{Cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/nov/07/bolland-strategy-marks-spencer | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Julia | last=Finch | title=Bolland looks to middle England and overseas for Marks & Spencer blueprint | date=7 November 2010}} On 11 November 2013, Marks & Spencer announced "that it is set to have about 80 stores open in the region by 2016 as part of its strategy to become a leading international, multichannel retailer" with partner Reliance Retail.{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/retail-news/mass-off-price/marks-spencer-to-expand-in-india-7272370?src=nl/mornReport/20131112 | title=Marks & Spencer to Expand in India | publisher=WWD | date=11 November 2013 | accessdate=12 November 2013 | author=Conti, Samantha}} It opened a flagship store in Bandra in Mumbai. M&S sales of lingerie accounts for more than a fifth of the sales in the Indian market, with total lingerie sales increasing by a third during the last six months of 2013. In May 2014 Marks & Spencer announced that their intention was now to open 100 stores in the country by 2016.{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2014/05/20/m-s-india-idINKBN0E00TU20140520|title=Marks & Spencer plans to open 100 stores in India by 2016|work=reuters.com|accessdate=20 March 2015}} In the Netherlands, as of 2015, M&S have a supermarket in the expensive [[Kalverstraat]] shopping street in Amsterdam, as well as a larger store including clothing in [[The Hague]]. A number of [[British Petroleum|BP]] gas stations in the Western area of the Netherlands include M&S [[convenience food]] stores.{{cite web|url=http://www.marksandspencer.eu/Our-Stores/store-finder,en_NL,pg.html |title=M&S Store Finder - Netherlands |publisher=M&S.eu |accessdate=9 November 2015}} In 2016, M&S is due to open a much larger store in Amsterdam, with a direct underground link to a new metro station.{{cite web|url=http://www.at5.nl/artikelen/149435/luxe-warenhuizen-aan-rokin-krijgen-eigen-tunnel-naar-noordzuidlijn-station |title=Luxe warenhuizen aan Rokin krijgen eigen tunnel naar Noord/Zuidlijn-station |publisher=AT5.nl |date=9 November 2015 |accessdate=9 November 2015}} ==Store formats== ===Core shops=== [[File:Marks and Spencer.Kirkcaldy.JPG|thumb|A typical example of an un-modernised 'core' M&S store, located in [[Kirkcaldy]], [[Fife]]. However, as of 2012 the store has now been fully refurbished with the so-called "Light Touch" re-fit.]] M&S core shops typically feature a selection of the company's clothing ranges and an M&S [[food hall]]. The range of clothing sold and the space given to it depends on the location and customer demographic (an example would be that some London shops do not stock the Classic Collection, but stock Limited Collection and a full Autograph range). Most core shops feature a Food hall. The current store format was designed by Urban Salon Architects in 2009.{{Cite news|url=http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article2586665.ece |title=Marks and sparks: Shopping in the 21st century |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=27 May 2007 |accessdate=7 November 2009 |first=Paul |last=Rodgers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118145633/http://news.independent.co.uk/uk/this_britain/article2586665.ece |archivedate=18 January 2008 |df= }} ===M&S Foodhall=== [[File:M&S Food Hall, SUTTON, Surrey, Greater London.jpg|thumb|An M&S Food Hall in the [[Sutton, London]] branch]] All the '''St Michael Food hall''' supermarkets were renamed ''M&S Food hall'' when Marks & Spencer dropped the ''St Michael'' brand in 2000. Each M&S Foodhall sells groceries, which are all under the Marks & Spencer brand. However, in 2009 the company began selling a limited range of other brands, such as [[Coca-Cola]] and [[Stella Artois]], without reducing the number of M&S goods they sold. This marked the first time in its 125-year history that Marks & Spencer had sold any brands other than its own.{{Cite news|url= http://www.brandrepublic.com/News/950570/M-S-sell-brands-first-time-125-years/|title= M&S to sell other brands for the first time in 125 years|publisher=Brand Republic|first= James|last= Quilfer|date= 4 November 2009|accessdate=22 November 2009}} M&S introduced [[self check-out]] tills in the food-halls of a small number of trial stores in 2002. Self check-out was implemented in the general merchandise sections in three trial stores in 2006.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb5245/is_200209/ai_n19869452 M&S to test self-scan tills]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} ===Hospitality=== Many large shops, such as Lisburn Sprucefield, [[Westfield London|Westfield, White City]], Cribbs Causeway and [[Newcastle-upon-Tyne]], also offer other hospitality outlets, such as a modern ''Deli Bar'' (champagne, canapés, seafood), ''Restaurant'' (table service—the first of which was opened in Newcastle) ''M&S Kitchen'' (traditional home cooking & lunches) or ''Hot Food To Go'' (burgers, chips, soups). Many of these outlets are run in conjunction with [[Compass Group]] under franchise arrangements.{{cite web|url=http://www.catererandhotelkeeper.co.uk/articles/19/4/2013/348189/compass-group-signs-m-s-franchise-agreement.htm|title=Compass Group signs M&S franchise agreement|publisher=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|date=19 April 2013|accessdate=12 March 2014}} ===Home stores=== In 2007, M&S announced that new, dedicated shops for home furnishings were to be launched. Shops have now been opened in [[Cheltenham]] in Gloucestershire, [[Tunbridge Wells]] in Kent, [[Lisburn]] Sprucefield in Northern Ireland[http://www.retail-week.com/Stores/theres_no_place_like_home.html There is no place like home] Retail Week and in the Barton Square section of [[Trafford Centre|The Trafford Centre]], Manchester.{{cite web |url=http://www.shopping-centre.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/2591/Trafford_extends_Barton_Square_homewares_offer.html |title=Trafford extends Barton Square homewares offer |publisher=Shopping-centre.co.uk |date=19 May 2008 |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725092414/http://www.shopping-centre.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/2591/Trafford_extends_Barton_Square_homewares_offer.html |archivedate=25 July 2011 }} ===Outlet stores=== As of 2010, M&S have 50 outlet stores and growth expansion plans for future.{{cite web|url=http://annualreport.marksandspencer.com/about/uk-international.aspx |title=Annual Report 2009 |year=2009 |publisher=Marks & Spencer |accessdate=25 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090723122137/http://annualreport.marksandspencer.com/about/uk-international.aspx |archivedate=23 July 2009 }} The Outlet division offers M&S products with the majority of them discounting at least 30% from the original selling price.{{cite web|url=http://www2.marksandspencer.com/thecompany/our_stores/outlet.shtml |title=Outlet |publisher=Marks and Spencer |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714041208/http://www2.marksandspencer.com/thecompany/our_stores/outlet.shtml |archivedate=14 July 2011 |df= }} The first of these stores opened at [[Ashford, Kent|Ashford]] in Kent in 2000. Many of the Outlet shops are in locations such as retail parks and outlet centres, though some, including the shop in [[Woolwich]], South London{{cite web|url=http://www.misterwhat.co.uk/company/146221-marks-spencer-outlet-london |title=Woolwich outlet from |publisher=MisterWhat |date=12 May 2014}} and [[Newton Abbot]], Devon were previously main M&S shops which converted to the Outlet format. Meadow Bank Outlet Store in Edinburgh became the model for all the Marks and Spencer Outlet shop in the early months of 2010. There are now also stores which combine a mainline M&S store and an Outlet store to create a store which offers both the main current full-price M&S ranges and the discounted Outlet ranges: one such store is at the [[Lewisham Shopping Centre]], where the previously closed upper level of the M&S store was reopened in January 2009 as an Outlet format sub-store;{{cite web|url=http://www.lewishamcentre.co.uk/stores/atozofstores/20314.aspx |title=M&S Outlet on Lewisham Shopping Centre website |publisher=Lewishamcentre.co.uk |accessdate=18 April 2011}} ===M&S Simply Food=== [[File:Marks and Spencer, Banstead, Surrey - geograph.org.uk - 339773.jpg|thumb|M&S Simply Food in [[Banstead]], Surrey]] [[File:M&S Food to Go, SUTTON, Surrey, Greater London.jpg|thumb|An M&S Food to Go store in Sutton station, [[Sutton, London]]]] M&S launched a convenience format, branded ''Simply Food'' in 2001, with the first stores opening in [[Twickenham]] and [[Surbiton]]. The stores predominantly sell food but also carry a small selection of general merchandise.{{cite news|last1=Finch|first1=Julia|title=Simply Food to triple in size with restaurant plan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/nov/08/marksspencer.supermarkets|accessdate=20 January 2015|work=The Guardian|date=8 November 2006}} A number of these are run under [[franchising|franchise]] agreements: * [[SSP Group]] runs the stores at mainline railway stations and airports.[http://www.ssp-intl.com/SSPInternet/Content/Brands/National.htm Select Service Partner]. Company Website * [[Moto Hospitality|Moto]] has stores at 37 of its motorway service stations.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6136684.stm Perils of the motorway pit stops] May, Maurice — BBC News Online – 10 November 2006 * [[BP]] has over 120 petrol stations with ''Simply Food'' offerings.{{cite web|url=http://www.bp.com/retail/sectiongenericarticle.do?categoryId=9036797&contentId=7067920|title=M&S Simply Food at BP Connect|accessdate=9 July 2011}} Orders from M&S accounted for more than half of [[Uniq plc|Uniq]]'s food product supplies to UK retailers in 2010 after several years service as a major M&S food product supplier.{{cite web|url=http://www.foodmanufacture.co.uk/Business-News/Uniq-Brands-will-drive-footfall-at-M-S-but-not-in-the-desserts-fixture |title=Uniq: Brands will drive footfall at M&S, but not in the desserts fixture |publisher=Foodmanufacture.co.uk |date=23 July 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} In 2011 it was noted that M&S were operating [[express pricing]]; i.e., charging more in their Simply Food branches than in regular branches. A spokesperson stated that "prices are a little higher than at our high street stores but this reflects the fact that these stores are open longer and are highly convenient for customers on the move".{{cite web|url=http://www.confused.com/money/articles/mystery-shop-how-much-more-do-you-pay-in-m-s-simply-food#ixzz2V8aHbrYr|title=Mystery shop: How much do you pay in M&S Simply Food?|publisher=[[Confused.com]]|accessdate=3 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927074743/http://www.confused.com/money/articles/mystery-shop-how-much-more-do-you-pay-in-m-s-simply-food#ixzz2V8aHbrYr|archivedate=27 September 2013}} The Simply Food brand has been phased out in all stand-alone larger stores since the rebrand in 2015 and the stores have now been branded as "M&S Foodhall."{{Cite news|url=http://www.bathchronicle.co.uk/marks-spencer-open-m-s-foodhall-bath/story-28652896-detail/story.html|title=Marks & Spencer to open an M&S Foodhall in Bath|date=2 February 2016|work=Bath Chronicle|accessdate=21 March 2017}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ===Online services=== Products could be ordered online since the mid-2000s, in response to [[Tesco]] launching their pioneering [[Tesco.com]] home shopping delivery service in the early 2000s. Both Tesco, M&S and others are expanding rapidly into this new niche market.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-39743611|title=M&S online food delivery service will be no piece of cake|last=Plummer|first=Robert|date=28 April 2017|work=BBC News|accessdate=5 May 2017}} The online flower service was accused of unfair trading and using [[Google]] to piggy-back advertise on online searches aimed at [[Interflora]] online in 2010.{{Cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11531677 |publisher=BBC News | title=Interflora sues Marks & Spencer over Google ad links | date=13 October 2010}} The [[John Lewis (department store)|John Lewis]] shopping chain beat M&S to the title of the UK's best high-street website by late 2010.{{cite web|last=Bold |first=Ben |url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/channel/DigitalMedia/article/1035596/John-Lewis-beats-M-S-UKs-best-high-street-website/ |title=John Lewis beats M&S as UK's best high-street website |work=Marketing magazine |date=19 October 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} As of May 2013, the Republic of Ireland now handles more than 50% of online trade. ==Product line history== {{Main article|List of Marks & Spencer brands}} [[File:PercyPigs.jpeg|thumb|upright|Marks & Spencer Percy Pigs]] The company's ranges include clothing for men, woman and children, as well as home products and food.{{cite web|url=http://www.marksandspencer.com/|title=Welcome to Marks & Spencer|website=www.marksandspencer.com|accessdate=5 May 2017}} Within these ranges, M&S use a number of own brands, such as those used within its womenswear division, including Indigo Collection Junior, Indigo Collection and Portfolio. Indigo Collection is aimed at women over 30s, while Portfolio is aimed at those aged over 45. By 2010, M&S had 10 sub-brands within womenswear and 6 sub-brands within menswear, following a reduction in brands.{{Cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/8098977/MandS-plans-to-take-Twiggy-international.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=James | last=Hall | title=M&S plans to take Twiggy international | date=30 October 2010}} Marks & Spencer were selling clothes under the ''St Margaret'' and ''St Michael'' label by the mid-1950s and launched their [[school uniforms]] in the early 1950s, but would be scrapped in the early 2000s as part of the corporate modernisation plan. Within Marks & Spencer's food ranges, it first pioneered boil-in-the-bag and sachet meals in 1972. The company also sells main meals, lunches, sweets and other savoury items. It launched its "[[Percy Pig]]s" sweets in 1995,{{Cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/high-on-the-hog-how-percy-pig-came-to-dominate-the-sweetie-market-and-win-the-nations-hearts-1989583.html | location=London | work=The Independent | date=6 June 2010 | title=High on the hog: How Percy Pig came to dominate the sweetie market, and win the nation's hearts}} and the billionth "Percy Pig" sweet was sold by October 2007. M&S also has an extensive wine and beer range,{{cite web|url=http://www.marksandspencer.com/Wine-Food-Wine/b/44092030?ie=UTF8&intid=gnav_food-wine_wine |title=Wine : Food & Wine |publisher=Marks & Spencer |accessdate=7 November 2009}} which was first started in 1973. In 2006 and 2007, M&S entered over a hundred of its own wines into two wine competitions, ''[[Decanter (magazine)|The Decanter World Wine Awards]]'' and the International Wine Challenge. Both years, almost every wine won an award, ranging from the 2005 Secano Pinot Noir, Leyda Valley, Chile (Best Pinot Noir in the world for under £10) to the Rosada Cava (Commended).{{cite web|url=http://www.decanter.com/worldwineawards/2007/dwwa_search.php?rsearch=M%26S |title=Decanter World Wine Awards 2007 |publisher=Decanter.com |accessdate=18 April 2011}}'' M&S's relatively successful interior design 'Home' brand was launched in 2005 and featured products like vases, furniture and beds. The children's online only 'Living the Dream' range of [[Lewis Hamilton]] and [[Heikki Kovalainen]] memorabilia and merchandise was launched in September 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.lewishamilton.com/news/2009/09/mandslaunch09 |title=Pit-stop press! M&S launches 'Living the Dream' boyswear collection |publisher=Lewis Hamilton.com |date=17 September 2009 |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713203035/http://www.lewishamilton.com/news/2009/09/mandslaunch09 |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.lewishamilton.com/news/2009/09/mandswestfields09 |title=News : Lewis, Heikki and M&S take over Westfields in London |publisher=Lewis Hamilton.com |date=19 September 2009 |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713203115/http://www.lewishamilton.com/news/2009/09/mandswestfields09 |archivedate=13 July 2011 |df= }} Merchandise also relating to fellow racing driver [[Jenson Button]] was added to the range during April 2010.{{cite web|last=Thomas |first=Joe |url=http://www.marketingmagazine.co.uk/news/rss/995553/M-S-supports-clothing-range-Lewis-Hamilton-Jenson-Button/ |title=M&S supports clothing range with Lewis Hamilton and Jenson Button |work=Marketing magazine |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} M&S launched its "Plus Fit" range for overweight children in selected stores in July 2010. It has proven to be a popular line.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefamilygp.com/M-and-S-trials-plus-fit-schoolwear-for-overweight-children.htm |title=M&S launches school-wear for obese kids, sells out |publisher=Thefamilygp.com |accessdate=18 April 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716235916/http://www.thefamilygp.com/M-and-S-trials-plus-fit-schoolwear-for-overweight-children.htm |archive-date=16 July 2011 |dead-url=yes }} ===Per Una=== [[File:Women peruna.jpg|thumb|Per Una's logo, three hearts]] "Per Una" was launched on 28 September 2001 as a joint venture between M&S and [[Next plc|Next]] founder [[George Davies (retailer)|George Davies]] with the contribution of Julie Strang. The ''Per Una'' brand has been a major success for the company,{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4329412.stm |title=M&S sales rise but Davies resigns |date=11 October 2005 |accessdate=4 April 2011 |publisher=BBC News }} and in October 2004, M&S bought the brand in a £125 million, two-year service contract with George Davies.{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3715654.stm |title=M&S completes Per Una purchase |date=5 October 2004 |accessdate=4 April 2011 |publisher=BBC News }} Mr Davies was to stay on for at least two years to run the company, with 12 months notice required if he wished to leave. ===Old labels=== The "St Michael" brand was introduced by Simon Marks in 1928 in honour of his father and co-founder of Marks & Spencer, [[Michael Marks]]. By 1950, virtually all goods were sold under the St Michael brand. M&S lingerie, women's clothing and girls' uniform were branded under the ''St Margaret'' brand, until the whole range of general merchandise became St Michael. The synthetic fibre Tricell was first used in 1957 and lasted until the 1970s. and another synthetic fibre called Courtelle was first launched, nationally, by Marks & Spencer during 1960 and also lasted well into the 1970s. Machine washable wool first appeared in 1972 and [[Lycra]] hosiery first came in during 1986. M&S launched their own brands of domestic products, such as [[washing powder]] and [[aluminium foil]] in 1972, under the brand name of 'House-care'. The 1996–1997 'Orient Express Tagged' brand was the first of numerous new brands, most of which were in feminine and children's clothes. The 'Orient Express Tagged' brand was part of the inspiration behind the 'Portfolio' brand. The men's Autograph brand was then launched in 2000 and continues to this day.{{cite web|url=http://www.marksandspencer.com/c/men/autograph |title=Autograph |publisher=Marks & Spencer |accessdate=19 January 2015}} In 2004, Sir Stuart Rose axed a number of brands including the menswear brand "SP Clothing", the "View From" sportswear range, the [[David Beckham]] children's range "DB07" and several food lines as he thought the company's stock inventory management had become 'too complicated'.{{cite web|author=David Birnbaum |url=http://www.just-style.com/analysis/sir-stuart-hands-over-golden-baton_id108297.aspx |title=Sir Stuart hands over golden baton: Apparel and textile news & analysis |publisher=Just-style.com |accessdate=18 April 2011}} A version of Per Una aimed at teenagers, "Per Una Due", was also discontinued, despite having launched earlier in the year, due to poor sales.{{Cite news |last=Craven |first=Neil |date=15 August 2010 |accessdate=4 April 2011 |title=M&S clothing brands set for overhaul |url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/news/article.html?in_article_id=512068&in_page_id=2 |work=This is Money}}{{Cite news|last=Hayes |first=David |date=7 February 2004 |accessdate=4 April 2011 |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-11737114-ms-and-teenage-frills.do |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130421120827/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/news/article-11737114-ms-and-teenage-frills.do |dead-url=yes |archivedate=21 April 2013 |title=M&S and teenage frills |work=[[Evening Standard]] |location=London }} The company also began to sell branded goods like [[Kellogg's Corn Flakes]] in November 2008. Following a review by Marc Bolland in 2011, M&S confirmed it would begin to reduce the number of branded items on sale, instead offering only those that it did not have an M&S alternative for.{{Cite news| url=http://www.ausfoodnews.com.au/2010/10/19/marks-and-spencer-may-cut-sales-of-name-brands.html|title=Marks and Spencer may cut sales of name brands|publisher=Food News|date=19 October 2010|accessdate=25 March 2012 }} ==Marketing== ===New logo=== [[File:Marks & Spencer corporate logo.svg|thumbnail|The older logo, used from 2000 to 2007]] During the height of the company's troubles at the beginning of the 21st century, the ''St Michael'' brand used as the selling label for all M&S products was discontinued in favour of ''Marks & Spencer'' and a new logo in the [[Optima]] typeface was introduced and began to appear in place of ''St Michael'' on product packaging. The same logo was also applied to store fascias and carrier bags. The ''St Michael'' name was subsequently adopted as a 'quality guarantee' and appeared as the ''St Michael Quality Promise'' on the back of food products, on the side of delivery vehicles and on in-store ordering receipts.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/674973.stm|title=M&S drops St Michael|date=12 March 2000|publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 March 2018}} ===Your M&S=== [[File:Your M&S logo.svg|thumb|''Your M&S'' promotional logo 2004–2014.]] When Steve Sharp joined as marketing director in 2004, after being hired by new Chief Executive Sir Stuart Rose, he introduced a new promotional brand under the ''Your M&S'' banner, with a corresponding logo."[https://www.theguardian.com/marks/story/0,,1804124,00.html Steve Sharp: Shy marketing whizz creating sparks at Marks]". Martinson, Jane – ''The Guardian'', 23 June 2006 ===High-profile media campaigns=== [[File:Marks & Spencer new logo.svg|thumbnail|Logo 2007-2015]] M&S has always run newspaper and/or Magazine ads since the early 1950s, but the introduction of some famous stars such as [[Twiggy]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/6636506/Supermodel-Erin-OConnor-told-to-have-cosmetic-surgery.html |title=Supermodel Erin O’Connor told to have cosmetic surgery |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=19 December 2009 | location=London | first=Urmee | last=Khan}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/video/2009/may/15/marks-spencer-anniversary-ad |title=Video: Watch Twiggy in Marks & Spencer's 125th birthday ad |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date= 18 May 2009|accessdate=19 December 2009 }} and [[David Jason]] in various TV ads has helped raise the company's profile. Twiggy first appeared in 1967, returning later in 1995 and 2005. Anne Grierson first featured in adverts during the late 1950s and most of the 1960s. In later years, [[Erin O'Connor]], [[Myleene Klass]], Tanja Nadjila, Peter Kay, [[David Beckham]], [[Antonio Banderas]], [[Claudia Schiffer]], [[Helena Christensen]], [[Tatjana Patitz]], [[Lisa Snowdon]], [[Dannii Minogue]], [[V V Brown]] and [[Carmen Kass]] have also featured in a few ads, along with many others. [[John Sergeant (journalist)|John Sergeant]], David Jason and [[Joanna Lumley]] have either appeared in or voiced over adverts since 2008. The new look has been instrumental in the company's recent resurgence, particularly with the success of a new clothing campaign featuring the celebrated model, [[Twiggy]], and younger models associated with the [[Boho-chic#The influence of boho|bohemian]] styles of 2005–6, and the new TV ad campaign for its food range. These adverts have the tag-line "This is not just food, this is M&S food" and feature slow motion, close-up footage of various food products, described in a sultry [[voice-over]] by [[Dervla Kirwan]], to an enticing instrumental song — most notably Fleetwood Mac's "[[Albatross (instrumental)|Albatross]]" as well as [[Santana (band)|Santana]]'s "[[Samba Pa Ti (instrumental)|Samba Pa Ti]]", [[Olly Murs]]' "[[Busy (Olly Murs song)|Busy]]", [[Groove Armada]]'s "[[At the River]]" or [[Spandau Ballet]]'s "[[True (Spandau Ballet song)|True]]". These adverts have been referred to by both fans and critics as being ''[[food porn]]'', with a number of other companies copying the idea, such as [[Aldi]] and, most recently, [[Waitrose]].{{Cite news|author=Kollewe, Julia |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/jul/04/marksspencer |title=Food porn for every hedonist in the world |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= 4 July 2008|accessdate=18 April 2011}} The 2009 TV advertising campaign drew complaints, leading to national press coverage, regarding sexism.{{cite news |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/sexism-complaints-over-marks-and-spencer-christmas-ad-14566626.html |title=Sexism complaints over Marks and Spencer's Christmas ad |work=Belfast Telegraph |date=19 November 2009 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} In 2010, it was confirmed that Dannii Minogue would be one of the new faces of Marks & Spencer. She filmed her first commercial in South Africa, which featured [[Cheryl Lynn]]'s "[[Got to Be Real]]", for their Spring campaign that aired on 24 March.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/mar/24/dannii-minogue-marks-and-spencer-ad|title=Marks & Spencer launches ads starring Dannii Minogue and Lisa Snowdon|publisher=The Guardian|date=24 March 2010|accessdate=13 October 2018}} Dannii travelled to [[Miami]], Florida in January 2011 to shoot the commercial for M&S for the 2011 Spring collection, prior to her contractual termination. In August 2011, M&S announced the new faces of their campaigns would be [[Rosie Huntington-Whiteley]], [[Ryan Reynolds]] and [[David Gandy]].{{cite news|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/Article.aspx?Id=TMG8731621 |title=David Gandy and Ryan Reynolds Join Rosie Huntington-Whiteley for M&S |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=30 August 2011 |accessdate=22 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313062227/http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/Article.aspx?Id=TMG8731621 |archivedate=13 March 2014 }} Marks & Spencer dropped a series of planned television adverts in the July 2011, featuring [[Twiggy]], [[Dannii Minogue]] and [[VV Brown]] as it started its corporate image revamp. It confirmed that Twiggy, [[Lisa Snowden]] and [[Jamie Redknapp]] would return for future advertising.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/8643936/MandS-drops-ad-featuring-Twiggy-Minogue-and-VV-Brown.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Louisa | last=Peacock | title=M&S drops ad featuring Twiggy, Minogue and VV Brown | date=18 July 2011}} On 31 March 2014, M&S launched the new iteration of its 'Leading Ladies' marketing campaign featuring figures including [[Emma Thompson]], [[Annie Lennox]], [[Rita Ora]] and [[Baroness Lawrence]].{{cite web | url = http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/1286622/emma-thompson-annie-lennox-rita-ora-unveiled-marks-spencer-leading-ladies/ | title = Emma Thompson, Annie Lennox and Rita Ora unveiled as Marks & Spencer 'Leading Ladies' | publisher = Campaign Live | accessdate = 25 March 2014}} ==Controversies== ===Israel=== Marks & Spencer has been criticised by pro-Palestinian activists over what they claim is its past support for [[Zionism]], and for fruit trading with Israel.{{cite web|url=http://www.boycott-israel.co.uk/business-links/133-marks-and-spencer |title=Boycott Israel Website |publisher=Boycott-israel.co.uk |date=21 September 1941 |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911025551/http://www.boycott-israel.co.uk/business-links/133-marks-and-spencer |archivedate=11 September 2011 |df= }} A shop in [[Brighton]] was vandalised in 2004 with pro-Palestinian and anti-Zionist graffiti."[http://www.indymedia.org.uk/en/2004/10/299453.html?c=on#c103995 Brighton Activists deface Marks and Spencer store] The company states, "We deal with politicians and officials, in government and opposition. We do not support or align ourselves to political parties and make no political donations".[http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/howwedobusiness/working_with_government Working with Government] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604154054/http://corporate.marksandspencer.com/howwedobusiness/working_with_government |date=4 June 2013 }} Marks & Spencer ===Comprehensive Spending Review=== {{see also|2010 Spending Review}} In October 2010, chairman Sir Stuart Rose was a signatory to a controversial letter to ''The Daily Telegraph''{{Cite news|author=18 October 2010 Comments |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/8069609/Osbornes-cuts-will-strengthen-Britains-economy-by-allowing-the-private-sector-to-generate-more-jobs.html |title=Osborne’s cuts will strengthen Britain’s economy by allowing the private sector to generate more jobs |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date=18 October 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} which claimed that "The private sector should be more than capable of generating additional jobs to replace those lost in the public sector, and the redeployment of people to more productive activities will improve economic performance, so generating more employment opportunities", despite recent job cuts of 1,000 staff.[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article5455026.ece M&S cuts 1,000 jobs as fashion sales dive], Helen Power and Marcus Leroux, ''The Times'', 6 January 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612031348/http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article5455026.ece |date=12 June 2011 }} This prompted calls for a boycott of Marks & Spencer and the companies represented by the other signatories to the letter.{{cite web|url=http://liberalconspiracy.org/2010/10/24/why-im-boycotting-the-35-businesses-who-support-the-cuts/ |title=Why I’m boycotting the 35 businesses who support the cuts, Kate Belgrave |publisher=Liberalconspiracy.org |date=24 October 2010 |accessdate=18 April 2011}} ===Contactless payment issues=== Some Marks & Spencer customers claim that the chain's [[contactless payment]] terminals have taken money from cards other than the ones intended for payment. Contactless cards are supposed to be within about 4 cm of the front of the terminal to work. M&S investigated the incident and confirmed the new system had been extensively tested and was robust. It had recently rolled out the contactless payments system, provided by Visa Europe, to 644 UK stores.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-22545804|title=Contactless 'charging errors' at Marks and Spencer|date=18 May 2013|accessdate=12 March 2014|work=BBC News}} ===Muslim checkout-staff policy=== In December 2013, Marks & Spencer announced that Muslim checkout staff in the UK could refuse to sell pork products or alcohol to customers at their till.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/ms-says-muslim-staff-may-refuse-to-serve-customers-pork-and-alcohol-9020982.html |title=M&S says Muslim staff may refuse to serve customers pork and alcohol |work=The Independent |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=22 December 2013 |location=London |first1=Adam |last1=Withnall |first2=Alex |last2=Delmar-Morgan}} The policy was announced after at least one news outlet reported that customers waiting with goods that included pork or alcohol were refused service, and were told by a Muslim checkout worker to wait until another till became available.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/10532782/Muslim-staff-at-Marks-and-Spencer-can-refuse-to-sell-alcohol-and-pork.html |title=Muslim staff at Marks & Spencer can refuse to sell alcohol and pork |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=21 December 2013 |accessdate=22 December 2013 |location=London |first=Robert |last=Mendick}} The policy applied across all 703 UK M&S stores and prompted a strong backlash by customers.{{cite news |title=M&S faces furious backlash from customers over Muslim policy |url=http://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/m-faces-furious-backlash-customers-174843463.html |work=Yahoo News |date=22 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160103021213/https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/m-faces-furious-backlash-customers-174843463.html |archivedate=3 January 2016 }} A company spokesman subsequently apologised and stated that they will attempt to reassign staff whose beliefs may impact their work to different departments, such as clothing.{{cite news|url=http://bbc.co.uk/news/business-25488259 |title=M&S apology over Muslim alcohol refusal |work=BBC News |date=22 December 2013 |accessdate=23 December 2013}} === Hijab as school uniform === Marks & Spencer introduced a hijab in its section of school uniforms in late 2018 and subsequently faced backlash and boycott from customers; the product is stocked for girls as young as three.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/ms-started-selling-hijabs-its-15268756|title=M&S has started selling hijabs made for children as young as three|last=Hodgson|first=Sarah|date=2018-10-12|work=northwales|access-date=2018-10-13}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== {{Portal|Companies|Food}} {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Burns|first=Paul|title=Corporate Entrepreneurship: Building an Entrepreneurial Organization |year=2008|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |location=Basingstoke|isbn=978-023-054-263-1|ref=harv}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Marks & Spencer}} * [http://www.marksandspencer.com Official website] * [https://www.loc8nearme.co.uk/marks-and-spencer/ Store Locator] * {{Refimprove|date=July 2013}} [[File:Matteo Bandello.jpg|thumb|right|Matteo Bandello]] '''Matteo Bandello''' ({{lang-fr|Mathieu Bandel}}; {{circa}} 1480 – 1562) was an Italian writer, soldier, monk, and later, a Bishop mostly known for his novellas.
==Biography==
[[File:Castel Goffredo Palazzo Gonzaga-Acerbi.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Castel Goffredo]], palace Gonzaga-Acerbi.]] Matteo Bandello was born at [[Castelnuovo Scrivia]], near [[Tortona]] (current [[Piedmont]]), {{circa}} 1480. He received a good education, and entered the church, but does not seem to have been very interested in [[theology]]. For many years he lived at [[Mantua]] and [[Castel Goffredo]], and superintended the education of the celebrated [[Lucrezia Gonzaga]], in whose honour he composed a long poem. The decisive [[Battle of Pavia]], as a result of which [[Lombardy]] was taken by the emperor, compelled Bandello to flee; his house at [[Milan]] was burnt and his property confiscated. He took refuge with [[Cesare Fregoso]], an Italian general in the French service, whom he accompanied into France.<ref name="EB"/>
He was later raised to the [[bishopric of Agen]], a town in which he resided for many years before his death in 1562. Bandello wrote a number of poems, but his fame rests entirely on his extensive collection of Novelle, or tales (1554, 1573), which have been extremely popular. They belong to the same genre as [[Giovanni Boccaccio|Boccaccio]]’s ''[[Decameron]]'' and [[Marguerite de Navarre]]’s ''[[Heptameron]]''. The common origin of them all is to be found in the old French ''[[fabliaux]]''{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}, though some well-known tales are evidently Eastern, and others classical. Bandello’s novellas are thought the best of those written in imitation of the Decameron, though Italian critics find fault with them for negligence and inelegance of style.<ref name="EB"/>
The stories on which [[William Shakespeare]] based several of his plays (''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'', ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' and ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' in particular)<ref name="SHEMEK"/> were supplied by Bandello, probably through [[Francois de Belleforest|Belleforest]] and [[Pierre Boaistuau]] whose stories were later translated into English by [[William Painter (author)|William Paynter]] and included in his ''The Palace of Pleasure''. Another of his stories includes "The countess of Cellant", a distortion of Challand, a northwest region of Italy.
==English translations of novellas== The only nearly complete translation of Bandello's tales into English is "The novels of Matteo Bandello", translated by [[John Payne (poet)|John Payne]] in 6 volumes, 1890.<ref name="PAYNE"/> This edition is separated into 4 parts, containing 51, 43, 51, and 21 stories, respectively, for a total of 166, minus two (part 2, story 35 and part 4, story 6), omitted because of their being almost identical to those of Marguerite the Navarre's Heptameron (stories 30 and 17), respectively, though keeping Bandello's dedicatory preface.
The Payne translation is a mixture of 19th and 16th century idioms. Examples of the latter include "an thou wilt" instead of "if you will", "wheneas" instead of "when", "methinketh" instead of "I think", "parlous" instead of "perilous". On most occasions, the language is clear and of fine literary value, but sometimes it is degraded with terms no one ever spoke or wrote. For example, instead of saying "Now I would gladly hear your advice on this matter", the duchess of Amalfi says: "Now I would fain hear from thee that which thou counsellest thereanent."
There is a second book of Bandello in an English translation by Percy Pinkerton and containing twelve tales.<ref name="PINKERTON"/> This translation uses a more modern mode of expression.
==Source material== The vast majority of the stories derive from those Bandello heard from contemporaries, reported as real life events. Far more rarely, some stories are based on literary or historical sources, such as book 5 of Dante's Purgatory (part 1, story 11), the Lucretia and Tarquin episode in Livy's History of Rome (part 2, story 15), story #23 of the Heptameron (part 2, story 17), and Francesco Petrarch's Triumph of Love from ''[[Triumphs]]'' (part 2, story 41). Some derive from English history, such as the chronicle of Mary Douglas, niece to King Henry VIII of England (part 3, story 44) and Henry VIII's six wives (part 3, story 45), some from Spanish history, such as Alfonso X (part 4, story 10). All of them were told to him by men, but a minority of dedicatory prefaces are offered to women. Bandello writes that the dedicatory prefaces to the nobility or to worthy persons are useful to him as a shield in case someone becomes offended by one of the stories and is tempted to attack him (part 2, story 32). He shows psychological insight into jealousy, in particular the description of two types of jealous men, the first from feelings of inadequacy and the second from feelings of the fickleness of women (part 3, story 47).
The most striking stories include two whores seeking to win their husbands back (part 1, story 17), two brother thieves in cahoots to rob the treasures of the king of Egypt (part 1, story 23), a disdained lover voluntarily choosing to live inside a cave (part 1, story 25), a woman killing herself only out of fear that her good fortune will turn bad (part 1, story 48), [[Filippo Lippi]], released from slavery in Africa because of his talent as a celebrated painter (part 1, story 50), a woman disdaining a man and then killing herself when he no longer pursues her (part 2, story 16), an abbot making music from a chorus of pigs (part 2, story 23), an adulterous lover buried alive and then saved (part 3, story 1), a merchant's murder of another (part 4, story 1), a case of double adultery whereby each husband cuckolds the other (part 4, story 11), and two women yelling at each other after being falsely told they are hard of hearing (part 4, story 21).
==Plays by Shakespeare== Four Bandello stories were adapted by Shakespeare, including ''[[Cymbeline]]'' (part 1, story 19), the Claudio subplot of ''[[Much Ado about Nothing]]'' (part 1, story 20), ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' (part 2, story 6), and ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' (part 2, story 28), plus one from the [[Shakespeare Apocrypha]], ''[[Edward III (play)|Edward III]]'' (part 2, story 29).
==Plays by others== Bandello stories have also been adapted by other dramatists, including [[John Webster]], ''[[The Duchess of Malfi]]'' (part 1, story 24), [[Philip Massinger]], ''[[The Picture (Massinger play)|The Picture]]'' (part 1, story 19), the same source as that of Cymbeline, [[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] and [[Jean Mairet]], ''[[Sophonisba]]'' (part 1, story 35), [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]], ''[[The Maid's Tragedy|The Maid in the Inn]]'' (part 2, story 11), the anonymous 17th century French author of ''[[The Cruel Moor]]'' (1618) (part 3, story 17), [[Giuseppe Giacosa]], ''La Signora di Challant'', ''[[The Lady of Challand]]'' (part 1, story 4) and [[Lope de Vega]], ''Castelvines y Monteses'' (published in 1647 and written between 1604 and 1618).

[[File:Mausolea and Monuments Trust logo.jpg|thumbnail|The Mausolea and Monuments Trust logo]] '''The Mausolea and Monuments Trust''' is a charity for the "protection and preservation of mausolea and funerary monuments situated in Great Britain and Ireland." The trust was founded in 1997 by the architectural historian [[Jill Allibone]] (1932–1998).<ref>[http://www.mmtrust.org.uk/about_us About Us.] Mausolea and Monuments Trust. Retrieved 20 October 2015.</ref>
The trust has responsibility for six mausolea:
* The Bateman Mausoleum, [[Morley, Derbyshire|Morley]], [[Derbyshire]] * The Heathcote Mausoleum, [[Hursley]], [[Hampshire]] * The Wynne Ellis Mausoleum, [[Whitstable]], [[Kent]] * The Nash Mausoleum, [[Farningham]], [[Kent]] * The Guise Mausoleum, [[Elmore, Gloucestershire]] * The Boileau Mausoleum, [[Ketteringham]], [[Norfolk]]
The trust publishes a regular journal titled ''Mausolus'', and researches and maintains a [[gazetteer]] of mausolea in Great Britain and Ireland.<ref>http://www.mmtrust.org.uk/</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
